Hi J.B., Jeff,
 
Thanks for the prompt reply.
 
I am extending MyTestCase from TestCase, as I am wishing to write a test
method in MyTestCase class as well.
Also, I am planning to club all small test suites in one test suite.
So there it makes sense.
 
Well, I did look at JUnit-Addons and GSBase, but as of now these doesn't
fit in my requirement.
I think I better stick with the idea suggested by Jeff. 
I can write a function in Overridden TestCase class, which will set the
boolean variable.
And inside the test method I can check for this boolean variable.
 
Once again, Thanks a lot.
 
With Regards,
Rakesh.
 
 
-----Original Message-----
From: Jeff Grigg [mailto:jeffgrigg@...] 
Sent: Saturday, September 27, 2003 3:40 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: Conditional TestSuite !!!



--- "Rakesh" <rakeshm@i...> wrote:
> I have a question on TestSuite.
> Can we decide at run time, which test cases we want to include
> in the TestSuite. Something like this
>  
> public class MyTestSuite extends Test 
> {
>     private static boolean required = false ;
>     public static Test suite()
>     {
>         if( required )
>         {
>             suite.addTest(new TestSuite(TestCase1.class));
>         }
>         suite.addTest(new TestSuite(TestCase2.class));
>         suite.addTest(new TestSuite(TestCase3.class));
>     }
> } 

In each of the test methods in TestCase1, you can say, at the start 
of the method:

| if (!SomeGlobalPlace.testsOfThisTypeShouldRun)
|     return;

Not pretty, but it can work.
  - jeff
